discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Gotta say, D makes the most sense.

questions.question_text: A global organization is deploying ChromeOS devices to all of their users. Corporate policy requires all web traffic to be filtered using an existing enterprise solution such that employees cannot access 1 million unauthorized websites. What should you configure to meet this requirement?

choices.A: A “Network access control deny" policy to blocklist the URLs.
choices.B: A firewall rule to blocklist the URLs
choices.D: A user policy to blocklist the URLs.
choices.C: A user policy enforcing the use of a web proxy.

questions.question_text: Your customer is deploying ChromeOS devices in their environment and requires those ChromeOS devices to adhere to web filtering via TLS (or SSL) inspection. What recommendations should you make to your customer in setting up the requirements for ChromeOS devices?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
When deploying ChromeOS devices in an environment that requires web filtering with TLS (or SSL) inspection, you must ensure that these devices trust the inspection process while maintaining proper security controls. The best practice involves:

Configuring a hostname allowlist – This ensures that critical ChromeOS services (such as system updates and device policies) are not blocked or broken by SSL inspection.
Setting up a TLS/SSL certificate – You must deploy a trusted root CA certificate to all managed ChromeOS devices via the Google Admin console. This allows devices to trust the SSL/TLS inspection process.
Verifying TLS/SSL inspection – Test web filtering and SSL interception to confirm that the policies work without breaking key ChromeOS functionalities.

choices.C: Configure a transparent proxy set up your allowlist to use *.google.com, then verify TLS (or SSL) inspection is working.
choices.D: ChromeOS devices are preconfigured to adhere to company TLS (or SSL) inspection by default and can therefore be deployed with no additional configuration.
choices.B: Reach out to Google Workspace Security and Compliance for tailored configurations for your customer.
choices.A: Configure a hostname allowlist, set up a TLS (or SSL) certificate, then verify TLS (or SSL) inspection is working.

choices.C: Use a third-party recording tool to monitor the site
choices.D: Pin the site as an application
choices.B: Lock the browser in full screen
choices.A: Deploy the website as a kiosk app

questions.question_text:
A school district has a new exam provider. They offer a website for students to access and take the exam.

How should the admin ensure this website is locked for testing on ChromeOS?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I'm vibing with B here.

choices.D: Enable SAML-based Single Sign-On for each application via Chrome App Management
choices.C: Enable SAML identity provider-initiated login for Google Authentication
choices.B: Use Chrome App Builder to enable SSO for each application and force-install the applications using Chrome user policies
choices.A: Enable SAML-based Single Sign-On for Chrome devices and Single Sign-On Cookie Behavior

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Looks like A fits best.

questions.question_text: You want users to sign in to Chrome devices via SAML and be able to access SAML-enabled web applications without having to re-enter their credentials. How should you configure SAML?
How do you validate Chrome policies on a managed device?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I’m going with D — the rest don’t quite add up.

choices.C: Go to the admin console and look up the policies
choices.D: In the browser go to chrome://policy to confirm that the device is receiving both user and device policy
choices.B: In the browser go to policy://chrome to confirm that the device is receiving both user and device policy
